segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā kassapagotto kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
segments.en: At one time Venerable Kassapagotta was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā kassapagotto divāvihāragato aññataraṃ chetaṃ ovadati.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Kassapagotta, having withdrawn for his day’s meditation, tried to advise a tribal hunter.

segments.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā āyasmantaṃ kassapagottaṃ saṃvejetukāmā yenāyasmā kassapagotto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ kassapagottaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then the deity haunting that forest approached Kassapagotta wanting to stir him up, and recited these verses:
“A tribal hunter wandering the rugged hills
It’s a waste of time to advise him;
this mendicant seems to me like an idiot.
The tribal hunter listens without understanding,
Even if you lit ten lamps
and brought them to him, Kassapa,
for he has no eyes to see.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kassapagotto tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
segments.en: Impelled by that deity, Venerable Kassapagotta was struck with a sense of urgency.

suttaplex.blurb: A monk named Kassapagotta encounters a hunter in the forest and tries to dissuade him from his violent purpose. But a deity warns him not to waste his time.
